*'[[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]]' *'[[ATP World Tour Finals]]'
* 'Masters 1000' *'[[Tennis at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]]' *'[[ATP World
  Tour 500 series|500 series]]' *'[[ATP World Tour 250 series|250 series]]'
  *'[[ATP Challenger Tour Finals]]' *'[[ATP Challenger Tour|Challenger]]'
  *'[[ITF Men's Circuit|Futures]]' ** [[Association of Tennis Professionals|No
  ATP Rankings]] *** [[Davis Cup]] *** [[Hopman Cup]]

The 'ATP World Tour Masters 1000' is a series of nine tennis tournaments that
are part of the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) tour, held annually
throughout the year in Europe, North America and Asia. The series constitutes
the most prestigious tournaments in men's tennis after the four Grand Slam
events and the ATP World Tour Finals.

Results in ATP Masters 1000 events earn players more world ranking points than
regular tournaments, though not as many as Grand Slam events or the year-end ATP
World Tour Finals. Up until 2007, most Masters Series finals were contested as
best of five set matches. Currently, all Masters Series events are decided in
best of three set matches.

Rafael Nadal holds the record for the most singles titles with 24 since the
Masters series began in 1990, Daniel Nestor owns the most doubles titles with
25, and the Bryan Brothers have won a record 24 doubles titles as a team. No man
has ever won all 9 singles titles in their career, with Novak Djokovic the
record holder with 8 of the 9 titles. However in doubles, Nestor and the Bryan
Brothers have each won all 9 titles throughout their careers.
